newsitem.title: UK: S&P raises SEB outlook to positive from stable.
newsitem.headline: S&P raises SEB outlook to positive from stable.

text.p: Standard & Poor's said on Wednesday it revised its long-term rating outlook for Skandinaviska Enskilda Banken to positive from stable.
It also said it affirmed SEB and its related entities' A long-term and A2 short-term ratings.
S&P said in a statement the revision of SEB's outlook reflected the improvements made in the risk management systems of Sweden's third largest bank and its financial profile.

"Over the past year, SEB has made good progress in improving its risk management procedures, especially in its lending functions, where controls and underwriting procedures have been extensively tightened," the statement said.

"At the end of September 1996, SEB's Tier 1 regulatory capital ratio stood at a good 7.1 percent. Continuing low credit demand in Sweden will enable SEB to keep on growing its capital adequacy in the short term," it said.

Although SEB's financial profile had strengthened over the past year, S&P said the bank would have to maintain tight control over operating expenses and maintain low levels of credit losses in order to avoid a dilution of its financial flexibility and creditworthiness in the current competitive operating environment.
